_prev_prog_3.Description: The prevention program applies to all operations within the covered process

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
FARMLAND INDUSTRIES, INC.
HASTINGS TERMINAL
HASTINGS, NEBRASKA


Farmland Industries, Inc. operates a fertilizer terminal near Hastings, Nebraska which is subject to the Environmental Protection Agencys Risk Management Program rule under the Clean Air Act Amendments of 1990.

The Risk Management Program rule requires a facility which handles threshold amounts of certain chemical substances to develop a program (if one is not already in existence) to prevent accidental releases of these substances and to minimize the consequences of those releases that do occur.  This Risk Management Program is to include a management system, a hazard assessment to identify the possible offsite impacts of the worst-case and alternative release scenarios, a five-year accident history record, an accidental release prevention program, an emergency response program and a Risk Management Plan which summarizes the entire program and is submitted to the EPA.

The following is the Executive Summary of the Risk Management Plan for Farmland Industries, Inc. - Hastings Terminal located near Hastings, Nebraska.

Stationary Source and Regulated Substances

The Farmland Industries, Inc. - Hastings Terminal, located near Hastings in south central Nebraska, serves as a storage and distribution facility for the fertilizer products that Farmlands member-owners need to grow the crops that provide high-quality, low-cost food for families around the world.

With an annual throughput of 100,000 tons of anhydrous ammonia and up to 100,000 tons of other liquid fertilizers, the Hastings Terminal serves as a vital link in the Farmland distribution system by receiving fertilizer products from the Farmland manufacturing plants, by storing the products until they are needed (by local co-ops for their patrons fields) and by distributing the products primarily in the area of south central and southwestern Nebraska.  Being centrally located, the Hastings Terminal helps to reduce the costs for s

hipping to the co-ops, helps to contain the cost of fertilizer for the Farmland member-owners and provides a convenient location for them to get their product.  In this capacity, the Hastings Terminal has served in support of Farmlands 600,000 member-owners for over 37 years.

The Hastings Terminal is a solid, reliable member of the Hastings community.  Its employees are committed to customer service and the facility is available to serve the member-owners as needed throughout the year.  Farmlands Hastings employees know that their customers are also their neighbors and strive "to always be there if someone needs us".

The Hastings Terminal has 21 full-time and 2 part-time employees, with a total of nearly 300 years of combined operating experience.  Although not large in number, these employees make a big impact on the community in which they live.  They can be found on the Hastings Chamber of Commerce, Agri-Business Subcommittee, the Local Emergency Planning Committee and are involved in area youth activities.  Farmlands employees recognize that community involvement and volunteerism are the most effective way to improve the communities they live in.

Anhydrous ammonia is the only regulated substance handled at the Hastings Terminal that is subject to the requirements of the Risk Management Program rule.  The anhydrous ammonia is primarily received by rail and shipped by truck and is stored as a refrigerated liquid at ambient pressure in four 15,000 tons/each tanks and as a liquid under pressure in two 200 tons/each bullets.  A large refrigeration system is utilized in support of the storage of the liquid at ambient pressure and various vessels and piping serve in the transfer of ammonia within the process.  Two ammonia heaters are utilized to raise the temperature of the refrigerated liquid from   -28 degrees F to 35 degrees F , as required for the loading of ammonia transports.  The anhydrous ammonia distributed from this facility is used almost exclusively a

s an agricultural fertilizer.

The Hastings facility was originally designed and constructed to be an anhydrous ammonia manufacturing facility and was operated as such from startup in 1962 until 1985, at which time the manufacturing process was discontinued.  Since 1985, the Hastings facility has functioned strictly as a terminal for anhydrous ammonia, utilizing the storage and transfer infrastructure of the original manufacturing plant.  Also, since 1985, changes including additions and improvements have resulted in the current design and operation of the terminal.

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response 

It is Farmlands corporate policy to eliminate significant accidental releases of any substance and, particularly, of any hazardous or regulated substance and to minimize and eliminate to the extent possible even minor and inconsequential releases of any type.  Prevention of accidental releases is critical to the safe operation of the terminal, to the safety of its employees and to the safety of the general public.  Consequently, the management and employees of the Hastings Terminal are committed to the prevention of any accidental releases from this facility.

To achieve its goals of accident and accidental release prevention, the Hastings Terminal is committed to the following:

7 a knowledgeable, motivated and highly trained employee group
7 a well-designed facility that is maintained and operated in a superior manner
7 implementation of a comprehensive Process Safety Management and Accidental Release Prevention Program
7 continual review and improvement that enhances safety and accident prevention programs
7 excellence in safety programs and practices, and a superior safety and accident record
7 planning, preparation and training for emergency response

The Hastings Terminal has had a written Emergency Response Plan - as required by the RMProgram and other EPA and Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) rules - in effect for many ye

ars and is committed to implement the plan in response to any accidental release to minimize the impact to employees, the community and the environment.  The response plan is coordinated with the Local Emergency Planning Committee and the local emergency response agencies.  Terminal personnel have interacted with these agencies for many years regarding the plan and activities at the facility.

Employees are trained in the implementation of the plan and  appropriate response activities that could be required in the event of an emergency.

Prevention Program

As a handler of anhydrous ammonia, the Hastings Terminal is subject to the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) rule, 29CFR 1910.119, in addition to the RMProgram rule.  Under the RMProgram rule, the handling of ammonia at the Hastings Terminal is characterized as a Program 3 process requiring a Program 3 Prevention Program.  For a facility with a Program 3 process, the Prevention Program required under the RMProgram rule is identical to that required by the OSHA PSM standard.

The OSHA Process Safety Management/EPA RMP  Prevention Program consists of a set of management policies and procedures which promotes and recognizes process safety and the prevention of accidents in facilities that handle, use, store and process hazardous substances.  The procedures address all aspects of facility activities including training, maintenance, operating procedures, process reviews, the maintenance and updating of critical process information, safe work practices, incident investigation, safety audits and other activities in a manner to provide controls to prevent errors, failures and inadvertent changes in a process that could result in accidents.

The Hastings Terminal adheres to the requirements of PSM and has written policies and procedures addressing all aspects of the PSM  and RMP Prevention Program requirements.  Specific features of the Accidental Release Prevention Program include personnel on-site 24 hr/day - 365 day

/yr, visual inspection of process equipment as part of the daily routine, continuous monitoring of storage and transfer conditions, alarm systems to indicate operating conditions outside the norm, automatic shutdown of ammonia transfer when control parameters fall outside a specified range and manual remote shutdown of ammonia transfer - as needed, refrigeration system for ammonia storage, safety relief valves on all lines and vessels, flare in continuous operation, level indicators on all storage vessels, daily operating logs with inventory records, inspection program for all ammonia storage tanks, bullets, vessels and piping, regularly scheduled compliance audits by corporate Environmental, Health and Safety personnel, monthly safety meetings and a continuous improvement initiative.

The Hastings Terminal has addressed the elements of accident prevention included in the PSM/RMP programs throughout its years of operation and remains diligent in adhering to and maintaining its Accidental Release Prevention Program.

As part of the ongoing mechanical integrity program at the Hastings Terminal,  three of the four 15,000 tons/ea ammonia storage tanks were taken out of service in 1997 for a routine inspection. After determining that these tanks were structurally sound,  they were  returned to service.  The fourth tank is scheduled for this same procedure in 2001.  The estimated cost for completion of the entire project is $1,600,000.  Also, a process piping and vessels survey was completed in early 1999. The cost of this survey was $18,000.  The survey is scheduled to be repeated every five years.

Emergency Response Program

The Hastings Terminal has both a written Emergency Response Program and a written Emergency Response Plan as required by the RMProgram rule and other EPA and OSHA rules.  The plan is coordinated with the community emergency response plan and is available to the local emergency response agencies.  Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-Know infor

mation as required under SARA Title III has been provided to the State Emergency Response Commission, Local Emergency Planning Committee and the local fire departments.

The Terminal is an active participant in the Local Emergency Planning Committee and interacts with various local agencies - such as fire departments, law enforcement departments and emergency medical providers - in its emergency planning.

Employees receive annual training in the Terminal Emergency Response Plan and also
receive various additional safety training, both in general, and in the competencies relative to their required roles in the emergency response plan

Five-year Accident History

The RMProgram rule requires inclusion of the five-year accident history of the facility for all accidental releases of regulated substances that resulted in deaths, injuries or significant property damage on site or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage or environmental damage.

The Farmland Industries, Inc. - Hastings Terminal has an excellent five-year accident record with no RMProgram reportable releases.

Hazard Assessment

The  hazard assessment element of the RMProgram rule requires the evaluation of potential offsite effects of "worst-case" and "alternative" release scenarios of regulated substances.

The EPA has defined a worst-case scenario as the release of the largest quantity of a regulated substance from a vessel or process line failure that results in the greatest distance to an endpoint.  The EPA does not allow active mitigation measures to be considered in the worst-case release scenario analysis.  The impact of the potential release must be quantified in accordance with the release criteria dictated in the rule.  The projected impact distance must be determined using EPA defined atmospheric conditions and is intended to provide a conservative estimate of the maximum possible area that might be effected.  According to the EPA, the worst-case scenari

o is intended to ensure that no potential risks to public health are overlooked but that the distance to an endpoint estimated under the worst-case scenario should not be considered a "public danger zone".
Possible causes or the improbability that such a release may occur are not considered.

EPA has defined the alternative release scenario as a release that is more likely to occur than the worst-case release; however, as with the worst-case, the alternative release improbability is not taken into consideration.

As previously mentioned, anhydrous ammonia is the only regulated substance handled at the Hastings Terminal that is subject to the RMProgram rule and, therefore, to the requirements for a hazard assessment.

Worst-case Release Scenario - Anhydrous Ammonia

Owing to the seasonal nature of the use of anhydrous ammonia as an agricultural fertilizer, to the limited rate at which this product can be received and to the fact that the demand for this product during the "season" can be very great over a relatively short time span, a large quantity of anhydrous ammonia can be held in the inventory of the Hastings Terminal until it is needed by our member-owners.

The largest vessels at the Hastings Terminal for the storage of anhydrous ammonia are the four nominal 15,000 tons/each refrigerated liquid storage tanks within which the liquid ammonia is maintained at ambient pressure.  Therefore, the hypothetical worst-case release scenario for this location is assumed to involve the catastrophic failure of one of these 15,000 ton tanks.  And, as required by the rule, the worst-case release scenario also assumes that the entire 15,000 ton storage tank content is released as a gas in 10 minutes.  The distance to the endpoint for this unlikely worst-case release scenario was obtained using the EPAs RMP*Comp Version 1.06.

This hypothetical worst-case release scenario is considered to be extremely unlikely to occur for many reasons.  First and foremost among these, are the

conditions and assumptions regarding the worst-case scenario that are required by the rule.  These conditions and assumptions are extremely conservative and improbable.  In addition,  the stringent design controls for this type of vessel and the facility maintenance and inspection programs which address the integrity of the process and storage tanks, including these, largely preclude such a massive and unlikely failure.



Alternative Release Scenario - Anhydrous Ammonia

A more plausible event than the worst-case scenario, but which is still hypothetical, can be envisioned as occurring in the terminal areas where anhydrous ammonia is handled regularly, e.g. in the loading and unloading areas.  Since the RMProgram rule does not require the use of a catastrophic vessel failure for the alternative release scenario and since the rule does allow for the consideration of active mitigation measures such as system shutdown safeguards (which are located throughout the terminal) and operator intervention to mitigate and limit the consequences of an accidental release, the release rates and total release amounts for alternative release scenarios are generally significantly lower than those of worst-case release scenarios.  Thus, the alternative release scenario could include such an event as an ammonia transfer line or hose failure, the lifting of a safety relief valve, a seal failure on an ammonia transfer pump or etc.

The hypothetical alternative release scenario for the Hastings Terminal is assumed to involve a break in a four inch ammonia transfer line with the passage of one minute before an operator activates the emergency stop system and with the passage of another two minutes before the release from the associated piping subsides.  The distance to the endpoint for this release was determined with the DEGADIS model, i.e. a publicly available model which is known to provide reasonable estimates of concentrations and distances associated with ammonia release events.  T

he impact of this release scenario is predicted to extend offsite.

Planned Changes for Safety Improvements

Safety improvements are a continual and ongoing process at the Hastings Terminal which is facilitated by the Process Safety Management/Prevention Program.   In a formal procedure, at least every five years, the process hazard analysis is updated and revalidated but review is also constant through management of change procedures, operator training, incident investigation and mechanical integrity programs.  As a result, changes relevant to safety occur continuously as needs are identified through these procedures and policies.
